comment: Toffee and dark chocolate, hint of walnuts and spice

I purchased my bottle about a year ago and had two drinks from it.  Today I had another one and the flavor is amazing.  On the nice coffee, dark chocolate some spice.   On the palate this is complex.  Chocolate, coffee, dark fruits and much more.  The finish is medium length with chocolate and tobacco.   A superb drink.
Very smooth, nutty aftertaste, builds. Very good.
Will be adding to the collection soon and with better notes, but Coffee, Stout, Chocolate, deliciously different.
A very rich, complex mix - a bottle to cherish, and something very welcome whenever I want something a little different.
Rich, dark chocolate - really distinctive. Maybe not for regular drinking, but outstanding when you want something a little different.
Chocolatey indeed!  Hints of dried fruits like plums and a whisp of smoke.  I like this best with a few drops of water.
Very nice by the fire after dinner - chocolate, mocha, smooth. More smoke than I expected , but still a delightful dram!
Great nose. Full mouthfeel of chocolate and orange zest. Lingers on the tongue for a very long and pleasantly lightly spicey finish.

Dark chocolate sweetness and orange peel nose. Smooth, rich body of bakers chocolate and darker fruits. Finishes, like a good chocolate, sweet and slightly bitter. Hints of oak and spice.  A good dram, but I expected more. [89/100]. [Tasted: 1/30/15]

Very unique---worthwhile splurge.  Tastes of dark chocolate and coffee.  Strong lasting finish.  Definitely not one for an everyday dram, but instead something to enjoy with friends and family on a special occasion.
Quick taste at Whisky Jewbilee 2015 confirms provenance. Must revisit.
Nose:spice and citrus.  Palate : sweet, with chocolate on the medium finish. A-
Dark chocolate, rich flavour. Beautifully unique. One of my real faves
I loved the chocolate, tiramisu, and almond biscotti taste.  Only 500 US cases.

Tasted this at Whiskyfest NYC 2015 at a seminar hosted by Dr. Bill Lumsden Glenmorangie master distiller. The nose was spectacular, the subtle coffee and chocolate notes were impressive. I can't wait to try it again.
Fresh cut lumber and citrus on the nose. Rich mocha and orange on the palate. Lasting spicy finish. Lovely.
Like a desert scotch, notes of dark chocolate and vanilla with spices
Rich on the nose, with a clear mixture of dried red fruits coming through. Not as smooth as the 25 but an ideal after dinner drink with the hints of chocolate
Delicious, smooth. Cinnamon and chocolate on the nose and on the front of the palate.   Outstanding. Bitter chocolate on the palate. Sweet. Slight citrus on the finish.
My favourite glenmorangie whiskey. Expressive and easy to drink. Love it! Little journey in every sip.
An absolutely spectacular bottle. Orange and chocolate, and a hint of smoke, smooth, clean, wonderful.
One of my favourites of the year. The chocolate malt adds a unique, complex flavour.
Rich and thick, this stuff is syrupy honey goodness.  Sweet with a hint of orange and chocolate?!  This brown oozes down your throat.  If you find a bottle, get it, you will be happy you did.

Ever had one of those moments where you enjoyed your life so much that you feel a bit sad when that moment ends? That's what drinking this whisky evokes. You could describe this whisky with notes like mocha, espresso, orange zest, and other flattering descriptions. But it will never encompass how fantastic this whisky is. Pairs well with soothing and harmonic music, like the Miserere from Gregoria Allegri.
Tasted at the Edinburgh Airport Duty Free shop on 7/29/2016

Had a dram during October 19, 2016 Glenmorangie tasting event with Dr Bill Lumsden! Never in my life I had a whisky that have such rich chocolaty on the nose! Follow with smell of coffee and malt. First sip, dark chocolate, expresso and some spices! Hmm.. maybe a hint of orange? Definitely my favourite Glenmorangie whisky~

Had it neat.  Nose - Rich, Cream, Malt, Chocolate.  Palate - Same, but dark chocolate plus expresso coffee, intense and smooth!  Some spice too!  Complex to say the least.. Finish - Very long! Slight citrus, mint.  Overall, what a unique whisky.  One of my favourites to date!  Delicious.

Stumbled upon this while waiting for my key at The Mallard Lounge at the Fairmont Chateau in Whistler. Only a handful of cases in all of BC. Can't recall a scotch ever presenting so chocolatey on the nose. With a sip, the familiar Glenmorangie is there in the background, but likely owing to the 30 year base the flavour is so much more balanced. For such a unique "roasting" of the malt there's nary a toasted or burnt taste. Worth the experience, but likely wouldn't go out of my way for a bottle.
Perfect on the palate. Beatuful fruity notes. Best drank on the rocks.
Frankly the best scotch I've ever had.
Ronde lichte neus. Daarna veel peper en hete kruiden. Een bijzonder frisse maar korte afdronk.
Unique and intriguing scotch, but not a masterpiece as some say. The cocoa powder is there but subdued.

Not for everyday but for a rich dessert style Whisky it's delicious! Excellent value as well compared to some of the richer ones out there. Definitely notice the coffee/dark chocolate taste with this.

Very fruity. Some butterscotch and spiciness coming through. Plums, dates, raisins.

Some woodiness and the palate. Dry, spicy. Got some prunes hanging out by my cheekbones.

Quite woody on the finish aswell. Grainy, nice and spicy. Very mouthwatering! Very nice.

Had at Swallow bar with my black friend Steve, his brother and Bud. We went to Porkies BBQ first and for the first time in history I didn't eat way too much of the BBQ. Had a real good brisket sambo, chips and a potato salad. This Glenmo was very easy down with heaps of dried fruit flavour and chocolatey stuff smoothing it all out. Wish I wasn't aware of the chocolate malt prior to tasting to see if I'd have naturally picked it. Really delicious and would love me a bottle of this. Medium finish. Great

Very nice dram, but would I pay $210 again after tax for it? Not so sure. The nose is caramel, sweet dark brown sugar, and dark roasted coffee. The palate has the chocolate with some major fruit currants. Black cherries as big as mountains. This all sounds superb, but after some oxidation, I started getting an off-putting banana note. If you like bananas (not for me) then you'll grant it 5 stars, hands down. It does have a nice medium length spicy finish.
The chocolate flavor makes this excellent for after dinner.

Nose, Chocolate raisins, an old-fashioned cocktail, cocoa. Peels. Palate, Sweet, syrupy cinnamon, dries, huge cocoa, oranges, lychees, malt. Finish, Dries and becomes pleasantly rubbery, fruits.

Although chocolate aromas all the way through. A fantastic dessert scotch.
Perfume & dark chocolate. It should also be noted that the cork weighs approximately three pounds.
Went down smooth. Had it with sankar on his deck.

Delicious, and quite different. This isn't your typical scotch, and there's enough complexity to keep your nose and palate guessing for quite some time. The nose has aromas of orange marmalade, toasted barley and tea - adding a few drops of water really brings out fruitier notes like raisins and figs. The palate is positively puzzling, with roasted coffee beans and malt, enhanced with a panoply of spices. As for the finish, it's long and dry, ending the taste on a high note. Cheers!

Put quite simply, just a fantastic company showing off their skills. Amongst my collection it's in a league of it's own and it's like pouring spicey, chocolate velvet down your throat. Anyone who isn't blown away by the sheer craftsmanship here should definitely not consider themselves a whisky drinker. A phenomenal drink which just oozes perfection and quality.
One of my top 3 go to drams.  Just an all around solid Scotch.... One you don't need to think about... Just pour and enjoy.
Could've been a high 4-star, but the spicy notes got the better of me. Otherwise lovely chocolaty coffee nose, smooth finish that is fruity sweet.

I had my eye on this one with a view to maybe picking up a bottle from Duty Free on the way home from the USA ($90 USD vs $200 USD from NZ retailers) so I thought I'd crack open a sample to see if it's worth it whilst watching the Lions play the All Blacks. Beautiful colour, typical sweet Glenmorangie nose with the scent of cocoa a hint of what's to come. Taste is good, definitely getting the cocoa / chocolate malt coming through which is quite unusual, slightly bitter or burnt. Dry, woodiness forms the base and translates to the medium/short finish. Do I like it? Yes. Definitely not the amazing drop it's been trumpeted, lacking the touted rich, thick syrupy chocolate I was expecting. Perhaps after many years on the market they are running of the better / older casks? Would buy a bottle at $90USD to see how it develops over time. Wouldn't pay much more though. Solid 4.

Update 2020 Dramfest. Another crack and meh still didn't rise higher, in fact I'd say more 3.75
Very unique for scotch. Chocolate, viscous, dark sugars. Very well rounded and drinkable.
An amazing scotch.  A nice touch of smoke at the very end. Crazy smooth.
What. A. Nose. Wow. Rich deep scents. First impression is jalapeño infused coffee. Some dark chocolate, yes. Zest. Spice lingers. If only the finish were longer. 10/9/17

Taste - Dark chocolate, skin-on hazelnut praline bittersweet, light fruity bitter orange pith, black peppercorn and cinnamon poaced pears.
Finish - Lingering dark chocolate bitterness, sweet nutty bittersweet, faint black pepper fading heat, malted milk candy sweet.
Score - 89/100
Final Thoughts - This is my favorite Glenmorangie expression I've tried thus far. The nose is incredible and I can feel as if I can nose it for days. Sadly it falls a bit flat once it hits the tongue as you're a bit overwhelmed by the soft chocolate bittersweet. I was hoping to get a bit more dark stone fruits, but those were significantly downplayed and overwhelmed by the chocolate bittersweet. The finish is long lasting, but is a bit one-dimensional as it lingers like you ate a dark chocolate malted milk ball and that's about it. Definitely meant to be sipped neat, although I can see this being turned into a super fancy chocolate/dessert old fashioned too.
Glenmorangie Signet is nothing short of spectacular!  A must have in any collection.
Gentle sweetness but very well rounded. Pairs great with funky cheeses.
Delicious, cocoa, spice, I get a little milk chocolate once water added.  Overall very nice, a real after dinner treat.  Lovely drink and who cares about the NAS when it tastes this good!

Neat/water

Nose:
/.

Palate:
/.

Finish:
/.

Wife's Comments:
.

** Disclaimer: This review is what I would consider a “Quick Hit”- meaning I won’t have my usual in-depth notes that I usually like to take. The reason: this sample was poured at Whiskyfest DC on 4/17/18. All of these reviews will not be scored and I am actively looking to try them again at some point to do them more justice.

This was a dram that @Generously_Paul and I talked a good bit about once we saw that it was going to be poured at the festival.  I’ve heard and read great things, but I don’t think there’s a widely available bottle from GM that’s worth more than $100.  So, I’ve passed on buying a Signet numerous times.

I seem to recall the nose being somewhat absent (keep in mind we were kind of rolling through the VIP hour so we didn’t let anything really sit for long) and upon my first sip I didn’t get any of the coffee notes everyone claims are present.  As I finished the generous sized pour (A+ rating for the pour sizes at the GM & Ardbeg tables) I really picked up a nice profile on the Signet.  Coffee and espresso notes lead to a fulfilling mouthfeel and lengthy finish.  It was a really smooth dram all around.  I’m not sure I’d pony up $200+ for a full bottle, but I definitely liked it.  It’s close to 4.5 stars on flavor profile, though.  Cheers.

Review #6 of 12 from DC Whiskyfest 2018. I was only able to do 12 because I came down with something that afternoon that really messed with my head and stomach. I should have just stayed in the hotel room but I didn’t pay $350 for VIP tickets to sample my pillow!
No scores for anything sampled as I don’t think it would be fair.

A very different Glenmorangie, but good. Grapes, fruity and vanilla on the nose. Something else I couldn’t figure out but whatever it was I liked it. 

Oak and coffee on the palate. Very good indeed. 

I may have to bite the bullet and buy a bottle.
Good, balanced but basic. Not worth the money. Maybe it has to grow on me first...
What a treat! Rich and complex with decadent hints of chocolate and plum
Very easy drinking; chocolate, coffee, light spice and subtle fruit. Best scotch I have ever tasted. I think everyone should have a bottle of this around for special occasions.
At Mark’s... complex, spicy, seems to have peat in the middle. Amazing packaging. 3.75/5
Vanilla, dark fruits, chocolate or some flavours from beers?oak and espresso, very good 4-4.2

The ONLY Glenmorangie that matters IMO.
Pricey but worth having in your collection. Break this out when you wanna stun your friends with something great.
rich chocolate, dry cherry, hazelnut, complex and smooth
very nice whisky with a hint of orange and chocolate. opens up more with drops of water. easily one of my most fav.

Signet is perhaps the most loved unpeated single malt on Distiller, so I brought a bottle back from England to test the hypothesis that I just don’t enjoy Scotch that much. I know, heresy, right? The nose of Terry’s chocolate orange, combined with the rich burnished bronze colour and the stunning bottle design definitely set you up for a delight. The taste is sweet, rich, long-lasting, with delicious coffee notes throughout. In fact, it tastes as good as coffee smells before it’s brewed. The malty taste I dislike in most Scotches is transmuted, here, into a kind of liquid tiramisu. So, reluctantly, I have to admit: you were right. It is divine.

Just did a vertical tasting of Glenmorangie and this one , as I thought, came as the stand out of the night. 

Really can taste the dark chocolate aroma and taste from the roasted barley!! Amazing!!! Also strong notes of coffee and some orange peel citrus. 

Glad I loved this one as I have a closed bottle stashed away!

Have you ever put whisky in your chocolate latte?.....Yeah neither have I but you can imagine what that would taste like. Well that’s basically what this bottle is. This has really old barrels in it along with their roasted or “chocolate” malt. It really does have a rich dark coffee/chocolate flavor. With all that and the beautiful packaging this is a great bottle to enjoy during the holidays.....or anytime really.
Not impressed, tastes some younger Malts in this

chocolates and an excellent cappuccino. leaves a warming and comforting finish with no tannins. almost floral and lychee on the front palate. mid palate develops to a chocolate and maple sweetness. long lingering chocolate aftertaste.
Mild spirit and chocolate on the nose. Charred oak and honey but no peat on the palate. A smooth and pleasantly long finish with distinct coffee flavour to end
There’s a lot going on here.

One of the few Scotches made with roasted chocolate malt so flavours of chocolate, latte espresso really come out but there is a light dried fruit in there not too sweet smooth and not too complex but one of my favourite flavour profiles!
This scotch is so delicate and delicious. It's got a balanced sweetness with enough body to keep you satisfied.

I have been waiting to try this one for years and finally bit the bullet and splurged when overseas. I had worked myself up for this one so much that at first sip, I was a bit disappointed. However every sip after kept just getting better and better. I had only poured a small amount because I am savoring this bottle but every sip left me wanting more and more of it. I feel like I could have drank the whole bottle in one sitting. Bronze in color and traditionally sweet like most Glenmorangies but one of the smoothest I have ever tasted. I thought the notes of chocolate were quite subtle and I didn’t get the coffee I was hoping for but absolutely delicious none the less. I got more of the dark fruits and spice than anything. Just when I thought it was over, the finish came rushing back and it was like drinking this all over again and I never wanted it to leave. I will always be looking forward to the next time I treat myself with this one!

Chocolat to the  nose.
Spicy to the taste, citrusy. Also chocolat to the taste. 
Finish is medium.  Very complex.

A dedicated solo #whiskyreview of the long-awaited Glenmorangie Signet. After reading all the great reviews about this treasured #scotch and overcoming the hefty price tag ($163 for 750mL bottle), I opened this beautifully bottled whisky for my first taste - ever. Before I start the review, here are some vital facts and stats. The #Signet is comprised of two unique types of malted barley: Cadboll malted barley and malted “chocolate” barley (often used to create craft beers). After being distilled twice, this whisky is matured in virgin American oak casks (as well as ex-bourbon and ex-sherry casks) and said to contain batches that are 35 to 40 years old. It's #nonchillfiltered and #nocoloradded at 46% ABV. Reviewed on 8/31/2018.
....…......….…...........................................................................
Nose: 95. Rich @Godiva milk chocolate. English toffee. Vanilla custard. Baked cinnamon buns. Tiramisu. Banana creme pie. I can literally sniff this dram for an hour without drinking it.
....…......….…...........................................................................
Palate: 94. Spicy ginger and zesty orange peel evolve into a creamy mocha and vanilla custard. Smooth and velvety texture that coats your mouth with sweet, spice, and zest all around.
....…......….…...........................................................................
Finish: 95. Long spicy finish with dates and dark chocolate that linger.
....…......….…...........................................................................
Overall Experience: 95. It’s a wonderful experience both with and without water. Although it's a #nonagestatement, you can taste the quality and age of this #whisky. Kudos to #Glenmorangie for this unique and outstanding creation.
....…......….…...........................................................................
Value for Money: Although this bottle sells for about $200 USD, the quality is not lacking in any way. Even the packaging is over-the-top with the cork that can be used as a paperweight. You will save this botle (and box) when it's empty. I got this bottle for only $163 @allendalewine
This is a wonderful product in my opinion. It really has almost all you can ask for a good drink, so filled with flavours is like a rich bouquet of flowers. Worth his prize in my opinion.

Too much alcohol smell, not enough Oak, too hard on the edges and packed way too much alcohol flavor, finish was hot and long.
I imagine great for hearty drinkers.
pulls no punches and hits hard.
Lemon, orange and dried fruit. Nothing particularly interesting.
Unreal smooth and sweet. I prefer complex and there isn’t much complexity here.
Smooth and full of notes of espresso, chocolate, caramel, orange, Barrel spices, floral, and later creamy vanilla.

Beautiful bottle!
Smells of malted toffee.
Tastes of malted milk ball and bitter orange/sherry with spice.
Great after dinner drink, lingers a bit like after dinner coffee.
Warms my face and ears.

N - 93: Light spices. Chocolatey/toffee. Aromatic

T - 92: Dark chocolate, coffee/espresso. 

F - 92: Very smooth. Medium finish. 

92.33/100
I got espresso like everyone else.  Very interesting, although not cheap.

This week, this is my favorite non-peated scotch.  It replaces my dearly departed 1976 vintage Macallan 18.  More recent Mac 18s seem to have backslid, and Glenmorangie has stepped up to fill that hole in my palette with this.

Except that it's completely different from your run of the mill sherried Speyside.

I don't much care for overly sweet scotch.  Years ago, Jim Murray rated the Glenmorangie Ealanta as whiskey of the year.  I couldn't tell if it tasted more like Bourbon or Brandy, either being way outside my tolerance for sweet.

But Signet is way sweet in an entirely different and less offensive (for me) way.  It is more of a dark, fruity sweetness, but I really can't place the fruit.  It is deeply rich, mildly spicy, truly complex, and front and center.

It almost begs to be chewed on and very much reminds me of drinking a stout, only better.

to be fair, this is my first experience with a so-called chocolate malt, so maybe it's just the genre that's struck such a positive note with me.

Either way, it's like taking my tastebuds and olfactory glands to the spa.  It makes me feel warm and coddled
This is an NAS I can really get behind. Much better and more complex than the 18, with beautiful caramel and chocolate notes and classic elegance. 95

글렌모렌지 시그넷 46%

캐드볼 보리는 크리미한 느낌을 , 로스팅 기법을 통한 Chocolate Barley는 시그넷의 녹아내리는 듯한 달콤함을 표현

아메리칸 화이트 오크로 스파이시함 강조


향 : 어려운 냄새.. 쇠구슬같은 향기가 다른 향기를 덮어서 느끼기가 어려움, 계속해서 깊게 들이마시면 옅은 알콜향이 코를 찔러보겠다고 날을 세우고 치고 들어옴, 그러면서 흐릿하게 플로랄이 숨어있음, 곡물과 꿀의 중간의 향이 절제되어 남, 점점 풀린 후에는 오렌지 마말레이드 잼이나 태운설탕을 덧씌운 향
맛 : 입으로 들이마시니 위스키가 혀에 닿기도 전에 달콤함이 먼저 혀를 적심. 스파이시함이 상당히 있고, 말린 과일이나 오렌지도 느껴짐, 
피니쉬 : 들이마쉬는 숨에 민트같은 화함과 스파이시가 느껴짐, 살짝 강하다가 열감으로 비뀌며 은은하게 지속, 커피향을 못느껴서 '나는 못느끼나보다'하던 찰나에 편의점 커피나 커피모카빵에서 나는 모카향이 흘러나옴!

This is my personal bar for a 5* whisky. Rich earthy tones dominate,  a product of the chocolate malt. Notes of tobacco leaf and smooth tobacco smoke (as compared to more campfire feelings of Islays). Fantastic finish.

This is a spirit that takes you by surprise. The nose is simple; almost non-existent. The first taste is disarming as well: a gentle warmth that glides smoothly into a finish with just a hint of dark chocolate on the palate.

Representing northern highlands

Nose: dry raisin, sherry, caramel notes, light oak, hints of chocolate, floral (heather), melon fruits. Really sugary and Sweet nose. 

Body: smooth, enveloping, so easy medium body

Palate: bourbon-y sweetness, creamy, medium spice, oak, apricot, malt

Finish: long, warming with milk chocolate, vanilla, toffee, espresso

Note: whoa, delicious, so smooth and easy drinking, creamy chocolate notes but a little spice is nice. A beautiful hybrid bourbon and sherry. So we’ll put together and super good

Scotsh Whisky Experience
Dark chocolate. Not strong even at 46 ABV.  a bit toffee/fudge.
Oak. Medium body and appreciable viscosity
Excellent spice and chocolate notes. probably a bit too pricey though

Buttery smooth with loads of complexity that are not limited to; cocoa, oak, tannic wood, carmal, coffee, fruit and slight banana. This is all going on while the mouth feel maintains the light airiness that Glenmorangie is known for. At $200 dollars it’s a special treat that will rarely be had in my shelf.
Sweet aroma. Sweet & spicy, mild smoky flavor. Smooth, easy finish that lingers.
fruity, it's as if a honeysuckle plant had a  butterscotch baby,mellow spice at the end

This one has been creeping up in price for a while so lets see.  

Nose - vanilla and believe it or not I get white chocolate.  Burnt caramel.  A touch of honey.  

Taste - Dark honey, light chocolate notes, toast.

Finish - sweet linger light oak.  

This is a nice pour and it's a shame this is pushing into the 200+ range.  At that point, I'd likely pass.  All and all if you want a dessert scotch this is a nice option but you really have to like sweet flavors.
Sweet and chocolate but not overpowering. The chocolate comes at the end and not really at the beginning at all.
Like the Glenmorangie 18 but less sweet and more bitter. There's a velvety feel to it like the Glenmorangie Quinta Ruban 14. It has a strong flagrance but the spice is a little hollow late tongue.
피트향이 은은하게 초반. 이후 바닐라향이 은은하게 주욱 끝까지
Chocolate and coffee, with a warm yet refreshing finish. Nicely balanced. Would love to get ahold of a bottle of this again.
So lucky to finally have a bottle of this one. Finish lingers and lingers. Amazing dram.

Nice deep dark scotch. Starts off with malt and chocolate and moves towards dark roast coffee beans with a touch of spice reminiscent of a rye. It has a smooth translation into a nice long warm malty finish.  It’s a good scotch but IMHO it’s not worth the money. Better scotch can be had for a lot less money.

Nose: Orange zest, cocoa, spices
Palate: Creamy, more cocoa, dried fruits
Finish: More dried fruits, some spice

First off let me set the setting for you as I was drinking this awesome dram. I was cooking a fine slab of meat for the girlfriend and I and decided while the steak was baking in the oven I would enjoy a pour of this juice.

On the nose even through the smell of steak was heavy dark chocolate and coffee notes with wood spikes coming through on the first time around. The second smells and I could get was soft baking spices and fruity with a slight chocolate finish which was odd considering the first smells were all chocolate.

The first sip coats your tongue and covers your mouth with a syrupy mouthfeel and not a bad one at that. The fact that there is little to no burn even on a first sip is dangerous and just makes you want the next sip that much faster. The first notes I got were of the wood which was surprising but immediately after the rich coffee notes came running and carried me through with notes of honey, chocolate, dark rich fruits and barley. The fact that this juice was rich and carried a heavy mouthfeel was amazing and served as a great appetizer for my dinner. 
The finish was not as long as I was hoping but it was longer than others and certainly more enjoyable as it left my mouth coated but not with a lot of the notes you get while sipping but more of as a reminder that your mouth just had something very rich and it is craving for more. 

I would highly recommend this scotch for any coffee drinkers and anyone that wants rich complex whiskey. I can say nothing bad about this whiskey except that it is quickly being consumed at an alarming rate and I hope to find another bottle at retail price to have as a replacement.
Lived up to the hype. Unique flavor profile with notes of coffee, dark chocolate, stone fruits. Really special stuff. I will always try to have a bottle around. I salute the "16 men of Tain!"
Bitter dark chocolate, roasted coffee, and candied ginger. A hint of vanilla. A dry finish.
Smokey, chocolatey, and other yummies. Seems like it should burn, but dissipates into melty, buttery goodness.

Thick legs, and a pleasant floral malt smell.
Initial palette is chocolate malt, with a nice spiciness, sweet, and a slight smokiness.
Finish is nice and long, spicy and dry at the end.  Very, very, nice.

Glenmorangie began as a brewery before being converted to a distillery in 1843. Since then, as with most distilleries in Scotland, it has changed owners multiple times before being aquired by Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy in 2004.
Glenmorangie is known to have the tallest necks on their stills in all of Scotland, at 16 feet 10 inches. This would be the reason why you'll see giraffes in some of the visuals featuring Glenmorangie name.
They use unpeated malted barley but once a year some chocolate malt is added to the mash specifically for their Signet expression.
The signet design is featured across the entire Glenmorangie range but only one bears the name. The design comes from Hilton of Cadboll Stone carving done in late 8th century AD by the Picts, tribal people of northern Scotland at the time, and is an important historical artifact.
While there is no age statement on the bottle, there's chatter that it contains whisky as old as 30 to 40 years.
On the nose there citrus and flowers followed by dark chocolate, lemon and butter cookies. The palate starts with black pepper spice and cigar tobacco then gets sweet with dark chocolate a bit of honey. On the finish, citrus flavors return with orange zest, lemon icing, a bit of brown sugar sweetness and biscuit.
Extremely well done with all the flavors layered instead of smashed together, following one another in a way that is complimentary and pleasant. The more a person sits on a full pour, the more different flavors they will pick out. My quick flavor notes do not do it justice.

This bottle, buried in my wishlist, caught my eye from the top shelf at a French restaurant’s bar. It wasn’t on the menu, but I decided to pay the $15 negotiated with the bar tender for a half-pour. Tasted following duck confit crêpe and crème brûlée. Nose: sea salt caramel, dark chocolate, toasted coconut, coffee being roasted. Palate: toasty, malt driven, yet still well rounded, layered. Mouthfeel: waxy, tingling. Finish: warming, light-roast cortado. Empty glass: dark chocolate, mellow tobacco. Overall: As unique as it is exquisite, Signet is a barley beauty, with layer upon layer of maltiness showing off from start to finish.

Typical Glenmorangie orange on the nose, but uniquely coffee and chocolate notes are also present. Silky smooth on the tongue, with spice and orange present. There is for sure espresso notes, but I don't find it as strong as other tasters. The finish is easy like Sunday morning, but there is some lingering spice like you may have had one dram too many the night before. A unique experience to say the least.
Smooth.  A lot of chocolate taste... I don’t care much for chocolate which is why this is only a 4

Sorry not sorry. Another Glenmorangie at 4.75. This guy is every bit as smooth as the Lasanta, but with much deeper complexity. Milk chocolate and nuttiness on the nose. On the palate, we have rich coffee character mingled with the classic highland earthiness. There’s fruit in there too, more like bright Rainier cherry than anything. Incredible long finish on this dram.
This didn't taste like over $200 whisky. I would have thought it would be smoother with more fruit hints than it had.
If you struggle to make the jump from bourbon to scotch, this will bridge that divide.
Kinda bland at first. Weak. Lots of caramel.
My favorite scotch that isn’t overly peeted

OH MY GOD. 
Oh my god. 
Oh my god.

This is, after 175 whiskies, the best dram i have ever had. It was only a 3cl sample but there is no comparison to this. It is fairly expensive (around $150) but it is worthy for its content and remarkably beautifull bottle. 

This perfect dram comes at 46%abv, with a perfect russetmuscat color.

On the nose is so freaking great, very sweet. As soon as i opened the sample i got an earthy aroma, and i ask to myself: peat? On a glenmorangie? This shall be interesting. Well, in the glencairn it became absolutely outstanding: sherry, toasted caramel, jellybeans (the most powerful note), some dim peat reek, old orange peel, sugar and cotton. Complex, sweet, dim peatiness, just amazing.

On the palate, the aroma promise became true. First sip: spicy pleasant elegant bomb. Ashy aftertaste. The rest of the dram threw me a lot more: milk chocolate, bitter chocolate, toasted sugar, hay, sugar, ashes, smoke, cinnamon in a superb way. Finish is so long i still taste chocolate after half an hour. Sublime. Full mouth spice and chocolate aftertaste. Truly a perfect work of craftmanship. 

I give this dram a perfect score, 100 out 100, it might just be 1000 over 100. Never drink anything else. Absolutely recomended. Even now i still smell cremè brulee from the glass that is 50cm far from me. 

I have now a new ruler in the whisky kingdom, long live Glenmorangie Signet.

Nose - dark chocolate, raisin, light citrus and okay spice
Taste - creamy sweetness, chocolate almond notes, hint of orange peel
Finish - light and lingering, gets sweeter before it fades.

Substantially better than the 18. Rumor has it that this dram contains stuff over 30 years and the nose definitely shows it. The 18 was great but this has zero alcohol on the nose and it’s at 46% which is crazy for that. It’s a dessert dram and very complex. Finish is very sweet and smooth. Easily one of my all time favorites. The price is extremely cheap for what you get. 100/100
Good but I expected more given the hype. I’ll have to come back to it another time.
Smokey at first, that smooths out after. Not the smoothest.
Chocolate, a little coffee, overall perfection.

This smells like Glenmorangie but you can definitely get the caramel and coffee notes from the roasted barley.

The classic Glenmorangie flavor definitely comes through but the chocolate malted barley really elevates the whole experience in terms of body and complexity.  There are great barley flavors, coffee, cocoa.  The body is thick and oily.  

This is really great!
Nice mix of spice and sherry. Balanced and interesting. Would love a longer finish. But all in all, a bottle I'd be happy to give and receive.
Spice & dark fruits up front with bakers chocolate & coffee on the backend. Balanced sweetness and hint of smoke. Very good

Nose- dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans, cinnamon, spiced peaches, ginger, candied orange, toasted oak

Palate- milk chocolate and almonds initially, espresso, ginger, chocolate covered oranges, creamy vanilla, bitter oak, cinnamon 

Finish- creamy mouthfeel with a long long long finish of baking spices and espresso, with chocolate from start to finish 

Unlike anything ive had. Nose is beautiful, palate is beautiful, finish is creamy and long with bright notes. The definition of a complex and unique whisky. Everything you could ask for from a whisky and more. Love love love it. Will be buying a bottle and keeping it stocked

Can’t give this a 5 yet because I don’t believe perfection exists, but this is damn near close.

Non aged stated whisky especially at that price point can be a concern but trying it once at a party and seeing it one sale at an airport, I knew it was meant to be as i had nothing but gold memories though vague they may be.

Down the hatch: The balance is remarkable and immediately you get chocolate, nuts, a touch of tobacco.

On the nose: mellow, fruity and creamy with touches coffee
1/8. 손끝에 살짝 묻었을 때 다크 초콜릿 향이 훅하고 밀려들어 옴. 스파이시하기보다 부드러운 목넘김. 마지막에 커피향이 burst. 전체적인 밸런스가 너무 좋다. 위스키를 어려워 하는 친구들에게 추천해주고 싶은 위스키.
Chocolate and spice. Initially an offsite on the finish - grass?  Seemed to improve with time. Opens up with a few drops of water
Sweet, and cherry and very smooth.

Sweet on the nose and in the mouth. Nice spicy finish. Spicy in a good way for me. Really enjoyed this one. For comparison to my taste, I enjoy JW Blue, Oban 18, Macallan 18 & 12, & Glenlivet 18. I’m a newbie, but have been trying new ones often.
The best I’ve ever had. 40th gift

Very unique whisky with a clear smell like espresso and a noticeable dark chocolate taste. It's very soft when keeping in for a while and has a soft finish. A great whisky and the bottle is just, this is a showpiece. It's special looking with the partially blackened bottle and a strong metal-esque cap

lemons, raspberry, malt and cinnamon on the nose
very rounded sweet taste. dried red and black fruit. chocolate and cloves.
long lasting finish which develops from  chocolate to caramel to more fruit.
One of the most complex scotches I’ve ever had. Front palate, mid palate and finish all could be explored for days. Heavy fruit, spice, chocolate and coffee
I had to let it sit for a quite a few minutes before it really opened up. It was all musty malt and old leather on the nose, dried dark fruits and light wood. Short dry finish.
